txt.en: 'Every man of Gondor within the Morannon is slain.'
'The morale of the defenders flags with these tidings.'
'King Eärnil tries to send reinforcements to Durthand, but they cannot pass the Black Gate.'
'The Thandrim do not know this, of course. They believe themselves abandoned.'
'Food stores run low, and hundreds fall to starvation.'
Talk to Annoth during his recounting of the tale
'There are... distasteful rumours.'
'But I do not believe them.'
'I have tarried overlong in the telling of my story. I will hasten the tale.'
'By the onset of winter, few only among the Thandrim survive.'
'Up above! The flying beast returns!'
'That is when the forces of Mordor come once again to Durthand.'
It is important to Annoth that you hear the tale of the Thandrim.
DNT - Blah!
DNT - Blah!
'Ha! You are a fool if you think we will.'

'I have heard tales of the bravery of the Thandrim for all my life: they were a shining light of Gondor's goodness, blazing within the shadows of Mordor. See them now, where they stand, defiant and bold!'
Annoth desires to tell you the tale of his ancestors, the Thandrim, who kept watch on Mordor from fortresses within the Black Land for more than a thousand years.
DNT - Blah!
DNT - Blah!

'Three only there are, but they are figures out of nightmare. Two are the beings we have come to know as the Nazgûl, the Ringwraiths of Sauron.\n\n'The third may have been a Man, once, but through the foul sorceries of his master in the Dark Tower, he has become something else. He is Ugrukhôr, the Captain of the Pit. He comes now to Durthand with an offer.'
'Bánor! Halannon!'
'We are cut off from Gondor! No one can reach us!'

'Should they have refused? Every man there knew Ugrukhôr for a liar, but the pit of despair into which they had fallen could not be surmounted. They had been hardy men, once, but a year of starvation and fear must have taken its toll. No doubt their fear was made stronger by the presence of the Nazgûl, but I can understand the draw of even the faintest of hopes in that dark pit.\n\n'The Thandrim surrendered to Ugrukhôr. Durthand was lost.'
DNT - Blah!
'Where are the rest of your men? This cannot be all that remain!'
DNT - Blah!
'These men can barely stand! Your supply of food must be gone, or nearly so.'

'The Thandrim cast aside their weapons, and beneath Ugrukhôr's watchful gaze they march to the Morannon, now held by the Orcs. The gate opens. Sixty men, all that remained of the Thandrim, pass through the Gate.\n\n'At a signal from Ugrukhôr, the archers on the walls fill the air with death.'
'I am moved to pity.'
DNT - Blah!
'You cannot think to hold this fortress any longer.'
DNT - Blah!
'Allow me to grant you this boon, in recognition of your proud defiance.'
'That is the story of the Thandrim, [placeholder]. Only Halannon survived, and his account is kept in the archives of Minas Tirith. It is Trenarn Bronad, the Survivor's Tale.'
'Surrender to me now.'
Talk to Annoth during his recounting of the tale
'Now you know the tale.'
'I might come back in a day with the same offer.'
Listen to Annoth's account of the Thandrim
'I might come back in a month, or in a year.'
Talk to Annoth during his recounting of the tale
It is important to Annoth that you hear the tale of the Thandrim.
'Will you still be alive to accept my offer?'
Instance: The Cruel History of Durthang

Talk to Annoth during his recounting of the tale

It is important to Annoth that you hear the tale of the Thandrim.
It is important to Annoth that you hear the tale of the Thandrim.
'Surrender to me now, and I will grant you safe passage back through the Black Gate.'
It is important to Annoth that you hear the tale of the Thandrim.
'The fortress is lost. Grant me this place, and you need not perish in its defence.'
It is important to Annoth that you hear the tale of the Thandrim.
'They passed the Black Gate unharmed.'
It is important to Annoth that you hear the tale of the Thandrim.
'I promised nothing afterward.'
It is important to Annoth that you hear the tale of the Thandrim.
'Go to your White City. Tell them a new Captain rules the Pit!'
'We must not despair! That is the weapon of the enemy!'
'Then we... we are alone.'
'What do you want, Ugrukhôr? State your business and go.'
'There are more within the keep. What do you want?'
'Why let me live?'
'I can see it so clearly, [placeholder].'
'Durthand, the Black Shield, proud fortress of the Thandrim!'
'It has been assailed many times, but still it stands in defiance of Mordor!'
'I see the features of Men whose names my family honours to this day.'
'Bánor the Steadfast, who never speaks falsely. Nanhad the Quick, a fighter of unmatched speed.'
'And most clearly of all: Halannon, from whom I trace my lineage.'
'In Gondor today he is known by another name.'
'The Survivor.'
'One year before the fall of Durthand, assassins creep into the towers at the Morannon.'
Listen to Annoth's account of the Thandrim
'All of the Thandrim were slain, save one.'
'Why, you vile creature? Why do this?'
'I say the tale is ended, but that is not truly so, [placeholder].'
'Halannon's descendants, the Sons of the Survivor, did not forget the Thandrim.'
'Neither did Ugrukhôr forget them.'
Talk to Annoth during his recounting of the tale
'The years and the centuries passed.'
Listen to Annoth's account of the Thandrim
'From time to time, scouts from the White City would find that Ugrukhôr had been in Gondor.'
'He had left one of the cloven shields of the Thandrim behind.'
'They were reminders of his cruelty.'
'Even now, a thousand years later, he leaves them still.'
